metadata.title: Janus applications: A mutifunctional nano-platform with integrated visual detection and photodegradation of tetracyclines

Janus applications: A mutifunctional nano-platform with integrated visual detection and photodegradation of tetracyclines
Jun Xua,b, Rujie Chena, Lei Jiaa,⁎, Xiaoke Shena, Tongqian Zhaob,⁎, Lei Sua, Shengli Guoa, Tieliang Mac, Beibei Zhanga, Qi Guoa, Zhijun Gec, Taofeng Zhuc,⁎
a College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University, Jiaozuo, Henan 454000, China b Institute of Resources & Environment, Henan Polytechnic University, Jiaozuo, Henan 454000, China c The Affiliated Yixing Hospital of Jiangsu University, Yixing, Jiangsu 214200, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Aminoclay@Au Tetracyclines Visual detection Photodegradation Test paper Milk samples
A B S T R A C T
Although there have been many studies on the detection or degradation of tetracyclines (TCs), there are few reports about the ability to combine the detection and degradation functions of TCs integrated on one nanoplatform. Herein we developed a facile strategy to synthesize citric acid and Eu3+ grafted amionclay@Au nanocomposite (AC@Au-Cit-Eu) that exhibited remarkable effect on visual detection, while the original AC@Au nano-platform displayed unprecedented visible-light-driven photodegradation efficiency of TCs. The results show that the AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanosensor can achieve rapid visual inspection of antibiotic TC in aqueous solution and real milk samples. The detection limit of the nanosensor for TCs was 11.2 nM. More importantly, the test strip made with AC@Au-Cit-Eu can also realize the real-time detection of TC through the color scanning APP in the smartphone. Meanwhile, the results also proved that the AC@Au nano-platform had good photocatalytic performance with a 93.33% degradation rate in 40min for TCs and the reaction rate constant was significantly higher than many other photocatalysts. This strategy greatly reduced the lengthy process from discovery to disposal of antibiotic residues and greatly utilizes nanocomposites.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As one of the most common contaminants, pharmaceutical residues in wastewater and ecosystems have drawn worldwide attention [1]. Due to a high consumption rate in aquaculture, human and livestock medicines, a large part of the drug contamination in water is caused by the use of antibiotics [2,3]. Tetracyclines (TCs), as one of the most important broad-spectrum antibiotics, have been widely used in human medicine, farming, and aquaculture [4]. However, TCs residues may pose potential hazards to natural ecosystems and human health, including bacterial resistance to antibiotics, serious environmental pollution, and chronic poisoning in humans, etc. [5–7]. Therefore, the development of inexpensive reusable functional nano-detection materials and the realization of highly sensitive and selective detection of tetracycline in environmental and biological fields have important theoretical and practical significance.
In order to monitor the TCs, many methods have been used to determine TCs, including immunological methods [8], microbiology [9], high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) [10], chemiluminescence [11] and capillary electrophoresis (CE) [12]. However, these
traditional methods often require cumbersome pretreatment of the sample, which often requires the use of large instruments, and these limitations limit their practical application possibilities.
Fluorometry is a simple and effective method for detecting trace compounds [13]. Since TC contains β-diketone functional groups, energy can be transferred to erbium ions (Eu3+) by antenna effect, the time-resolved fluorescence analysis employing Eu-TCs have been used for trace detection of TCs [14]. However, the intervention of coordinating water molecules often leads to fluorescence quenching. In order to avoid fluorescence quenching, foreign molecules can be used to replace the coordinating water molecules and coordinate with Eu3+, such as hydrogen peroxide [15], citrate [16], and so on.
However, the above methods have great limitations in practical applications, such as large rare-earth ions consumption, difficult to be separated and recovered. Moreover, these fluorescent probes could not achieve the degradation of toxic substances at all, but tend to cause secondary pollution. Based on the above problems, it is urgent to develop an effective method for not only real-time visual detection of trace tetracycline but also subsequent degradation of tetracycline. carbon adsorption, oxidation process, microbial degradation, and electrolysis have been applied to deal with antibiotic residues [7,17,18]. Photocatalytic technology, as an advanced oxidation process, has the advantages of almost complete degradation and easy operation, which is a green and efficient technology for the treatment of antibiotic wastewater [19]. Therefore, the integration of fluorescent probes with potential photocatalytic materials to construct nanocomposites is expected to achieve simultaneous selective detection and efficient degradation of tetracycline.
Herein, a simple method was rationally designed to prepare a multifunctional hybrid nanomaterial for selective detection and efficient degradation of TCs (Scheme 1). In this work, the aminoclay (AC)based AC@Au nano-platform was fabricated via one-step depositionprecipitation process employing different concentrations of chloroauric acid and aminoclay, which was followed by the further modification with citric acid (Cit) and Eu3+, resulting the final AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanocomposite. This AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanocomposite was then investigated for the visual detection of TCs regardless of various other reagents. Interestingly, the original AC@Au nanoplatform can also serve as a visible-light-driven photocatalyst and displayed remarkable TCs photodegradation efficiencies. These two practical application functions just like the double-faced god in ancient Greek mythology (which also calls “Janus”), one of which can realize the sensitive and visual detection of TCs while the other looks forward toward the photodegradation of TCs. To the best of our knowledge, this dual-function nano-platform that integrates a fluorescent nanosensor with a visible light catalyzed material is the first practical report to enable efficient detection and simultaneous degradation of tetracycline in water. Such a strategy strongly reduced the lengthy process of antibiotic residues from discovery to treatment, greatly making the best use of the nanocomposite.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and materials
sections.text:
Europium nitrate (Eu(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.99%), magnesium chloride hexahydrate (MgCl2·6H2O, 98%), 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimidehy-drochloride (EDC), N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS), Dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC) and HAuCl4 were supplied by Aladdin Reagent Company. Citric acid (Cit), TCs were obtain from Tianjin
Chemistry Reagent Co., China. Hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36–38%), tris (hydroxymethylmetyl)aminomethane (Tris, 99%), 3-amino propyltriethoxysilane (APTES, 99%), and all the other reagents were purchased from Guangzhou Chemical Reagent Factory.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of Ac@Au
sections.text: The composite materials were prepared by following previously reported method with some modification [20]. 1.68 g of MgCl2·6H2O and HAuCl4 (3.8 mM, 5mL) were dissolved in 15mL deionized water. Then, 2mL APTES was added and stirred for 24 h at 60 °C in an oil bath. After cooling, the product was centrifuged and washed several times with absolute ethanol.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of Ac@Au-Cit
sections.text: 50mg of citric acid, 10mg of NHS, 10mg of EDC and 10mg of DCC were dissolved by sonication in DMF: water= 1: 1 solution. The mixture was stirred for 4 h at room temperature. Then, the Ac@Au (200mg) was added and stirred for 24 h. Finally, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with ethanol and dried in vacuo.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of europium-containing clay probe (Ac@Au-Cit-Eu)
sections.text: 0.015 g of Eu(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 5mL of ethanol, Ac@Au-Cit was dispersed using 10mL of ethanol, then the two parts were mixed and reacted at 60 °C in an oil bath for 4 h. The particles was then collected by centrifugation and washed with water for five times.

sections.heading: 2.5. Detection of TCs
sections.text:
For TCs detection, 200 μL of aqueous of Ac@Au-Cit-Eu nanoprobes (1 mg/mL) was placed in a quartz cuvette, and Tris-HCl buffer (pH=8.0) was added till the total volume reached to 2mL. The method for the practical sample analysis was similar to the published method [21]. The milk samples were diluted with 0.01M Tris-HCl buffer (pH=8.0). We spiked TCs in the milk samples at concentrations of 0.3, 1, 2.5, 5 and 7 μM (spiked concentration), respectively. The excitation wavelength was 395 nm.
Detection of TCs on test paper: The filter paper was immersed in

Ac@Au-Cit-Eu aqueous solution (3mg/mL) for 30min and dried. Then a series of TCs samples were arranged, each sample (30 μL) was dropped onto the prepared test paper and the color of test paper was investigated under a 365 nm UV lamp.

sections.heading: 2.6. Evaluation of photocatalytic activity of TCs by the photocatalyst
sections.text: Photocatalytic TCs degradation was conducted to investigate the photocatalytic activities of the above synthesized Ac@Au samples under visible-light irradiation. Briefly, the Ac@Au photocatalyst (10mg) was added into 50mL deionized water containing TCs (20mg/ L) in a beaker and the temperature was maintained at 25 °C. Then, the above mixture were stirred for 30min in dark and then irradiated by a mercury lamp. At certain time intervals, 2.5 mL solution was withdrawn in the mixed solutions then analyzed on UV–vis spectrophotometer at the max absorbed wavelength. In the same way, we tested the blank experiment under the above light and dark conditions without the presence of photocatalysts.

sections.heading: 2.7. Characterizations
sections.text: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and the energy dispersive spectra (EDS) were carried out by a Tecnai-G2-F30 at acceleration voltages of 300 kV. The content of Eu3+ was performed by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) using an IRIS Advantage ER/S spectrophotometer. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded by a Perkin Elmer Lambda 950 spectrophotometer. Powder Xray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were recorded on a Rigaku-Dmax 2400 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation over the 2θ range of 5–80°. Surface composition of samples was obtained by an X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo Scientific ESCALab 250Xi). The photocatalytic activities of different photocatalysts were investigated by a 500W mercury lamp. The fluorescence spectra were measured by a Varian CARY Eclipse fluorescence spectrometer with a Xe arc lamp as the excitation source at 395 nm excitation wavelengths.

sections.heading: 3.1. Microstructure characterization
sections.text:
The morphological features of the samples studied by TEM are shown in Fig. 1. The aminoclay represented the approximate lamellar structure centered on the octahedral brucite layer, and the outer overlaying silica tetrahedral sheets, formulated as [H2N (CH2)3]8Si8Mg6O12(OH)4 [22]. TEM images (Fig. 1b) showed that Au nanoparticles exhibited diameter distribution with an average diameter of ≈8 nm, which considerably met the expected value, due to the catalytic performance of small-sized Au NPs was higher than large-sized Au NPs [23]. The detailed microscopic structure of the sample was further investigated by HRTEM image. Au nanoparticles supported on the surface of the aminoclay were spherical and the clear lattice fringes can be assigned to Au (111) crystal plane. EDS measurements can be used to examine the composition of the materials. As shown in Fig. 1d, the EDS spectra of AC@Au-Cit-Eu samples proved Au and Eu elements besides Cu, C, O, Mg, Cl and Si from the aminoclay matrix, implying the successful formation of AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanocomposite. A quantitative measure of Eu element can be carried out by ICP, and the grafting Eu content was 1.26%.
The UV–vis absorption spectrum of AC@Au showed a characteristic surface plasmon peak of small Au particles at around 525 nm (Fig. 2a), while that of aminoclay revealed no absorption band in the 350–750 nm spectral range, indicating the successfully loading of Au NPs on the surface of aminoclay. The powder XRD patterns (Fig. 2b) exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks at around 2θ=22°, 35°, and 59°, which was in agreement with the 2:1 trioctahedral smectite clay in
the previous results [24]. In addition, the peaks corresponding to Au at 2θ = 38°, 44°, 64.7° and 77.7° belonged to the lattice planes of (111), (200), (220) and (311) were visible for the hybrids (JCPDS Card: 04- 0784) [23], demonstrating the Au NPs successful loaded on the aminoclay. However, the peaks weakened in the AC@Au-Cit-Eu, suggesting the grafting of lanthanide complex in the surface of AC@Au.
Fig. 3a shows the XPS full-scan spectrum of AC@Au-Cit-Eu and the surface chemical composition of the nanocomposite were studied in detail. The wide-scan spectrum of the AC@Au-Cit-Eu surface was dominated by signals attributable to oxygen (531.3 eV, O 1s), carbon (284.6 eV, C 1s), nitrogen (401.1 eV, N 1s), silicon (101.6 eV, Si 2p), magnesium (1303.1 eV, Mg 1 s; 50.1 eV, Mg 2p),europium (1134.3 eV, Eu 3d) and gold. The representative peaks (Fig. 3b) of C 1s in the high resolution XPS spectra can be attributed to CeC bond at 284.4 eV, CeN bond at 286.1 eV, CeO bond at 285.0 eV and C]O bond at 288.4 eV in AC@Au-Cit-Eu [25–28]. The three peaks at 397.9, 398.6 and 400.2 eV decomposed by the N 1s spectrum in Fig. 3c further confirmed C−N−C, N−(C)3, and N−H bonds [27,28]. The Au 4f region spectrum of the AC@Au-Cit-Eu (Fig. 3d) consisted of two peaks, and the binding energies of Au 4f7/2 and Au 4f5/2 were 83.3 and 87.6 eV, respectively. This can be attributed to the characteristic doublets of Au0, indicating the formation of only elemental Au on the aminoclay surface [29].

sections.heading: 3.2. Optimal conditions for the sensing of TCs by using AC@Au-Cit-Eu as the nanosensor
sections.text: Aiming at fabricating an outstanding fluorescent nanoprobe, a series of experiments were carried out toward optimizing detection conditions. To study the influence of pH values, the fluorescent response of AC@Au-Cit-Eu was independently tested at different pH values (Fig. 4a). After the addition of TCs, the fluorescent intensity of AC@AuCit-Eu nanocomposite first increased with the pH value. This phenomenon can be due to that the increasing unprotonated TCs was favorable to transfer energy to Eu ions. The fluorescent intensity of AC@Au-Cit-Eu-TCs reached the maximum value at pH 8.0. When pH value was more than 8.0, however, precipitation of europium hydroxide could be produced, leading to the decrease of fluorescent intensity of Eu-TCs complex [30]. We further studied the time stability of the AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanoprobe in the presence of TCs (Fig. 4b). The reaction of TCs with Eu3+ in this system is very rapid, and the fluorescence intensity can reach more than 95% in 30 s and the maximum value within 1min. The emission intensity was stable in the following 20min. Therefore, we performed the fluorescence test after 1min of the reaction to obtain the best sensitivity. These results indicate that AC@AuCit-Eu had great potential as a convenient and fast probe for the TCs detection.

sections.heading: 3.3. Sensitivity and selectivity of the AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanosensor for the detection of TCs
sections.text:
Upon the optimal experimental conditions, fluorescence titrations were conducted to investigate the sensitivity of the AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanoprobe for TCs. Fig. 4c indicates the luminescence response (λex= 395 nm) of the nanoprobe after addition of TCs. The fluorescence emission of the nanoprobe prior to TCs addition was very weak upon excitation at 395 nm, due to nonradiative deactivation from vibronic coupling of the OH oscillators to the excited Eu3+. In the presence of TCs, the emission intensity of Eu3+ ions enhanced due to the efficient energy transfer from TCs molecules to Eu3+ ions. The typical emission of Eu3+ ions with peaks at 592, 616, 650 and 699 nm were due to the characteristic transitions of Eu3+ ions, from the 5D0 energy level to 7FJ multiplets (J= 1, 2, 3, and 4), respectively. The Eu3+ emission changed linearly upon increasing the TCs concentration and a good linear relationship (Fig. 4d) between the fluorescence intensity and the TCs concentration (0.05–9.5 μM) was achieved, as expressed by the equation, y= 47.9×+1.939 (R2=0.998). The detection limit of
the AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanoprobe was 11.2 nM when the signal-to-noise ratio was 3. And the detection limit was comparable to that of the previously reported nanosensors and was lower than many other probes, including e Eu(III) fibers (50 nM) [31], AMP/Eu coordination polymer detector (60 nM) [32], Fe3O4 MNPs colorimetric sensor (45 nM) [33] and thioglycolic acid-CdTeQDs-MIP sensor (2.1 μM) [34]. In addition, the probes reported here had a short response time to tetracycline in the assay, which was only 1min. The detection limit (4 nM) of the EueAg nanoprobe reported in the literature was comparable to our probe, but its reaction time to tetracycline was 3min [35].
In order to evaluate the possibility of the above method in practical applications, we investigated the anti-interference of the probe in the presence of numerous metal ions and competitive molecules. Milk is a common source of nutrients in people's lives. Milk usually contains trace amounts of metal elements, amino acids and vitamins et al. Therefore, we investigated the anti-interference of the probe on the detection of tetracycline in the presence of the above-mentioned
interference source. The results showed that the probe did not interfere with any of the above metal elements and molecules. As shown in Fig. 5, no significant changes in fluorescence intensity were observed after the addition of the interferences. These results indicated that the excellent selectivity of AC@Au-Cit-Eu facilitated the effective identification of TCs in milk. To further check the selectivity of the AC@Au-CitEu prepared in this method, other tetracyclines (chlortetracycline and oxytetracycline), and two other types of antibiotics (thiamphenicol and kanamycin sulfate) were also measured under optimum conditions (Fig. S1). These data indicated that AC@Au-Cit-Eu displayed a higher selective recognition ability for TC, supporting AC@Au-Cit-Eu as a potential tetracycline fluorescence probe.

sections.heading: 3.4. Detecting TCs in milk samples
sections.text:
In order to examine the applicability of this developed nanoprobe, the AC@Au-Cit-Eu was applied to monitor TCs in milk by standard addition method. The recovery values of TCs ranged from
100.23%–103.17% in the milk samples (Table 1). To ensure the accuracy and precision of the experiment, the same process was repeated three times and averaged. The relative standard deviations (RSD) obtained from the experimental tests were all less than 3.65%. The above results indicate that the nanoprobe can be used for TCs detection in biological samples such as milk.

sections.heading: 3.5. On-site detection of TCs by a test paper-based visual probe using a color-scanning APP
sections.text:
To make testing easier and faster, a test paper-based probe was developed using AC @ Au-Cit-Eu immobilized filter paper for fast and on-site visual detection of TCs. As shown in Fig. 6, after infiltrating different concentrations of TCs, the fluorescence color of the paperbased probe immediately showed a change from navy to red under a 365 nm ultraviolet lamp, which can be easily observed by the naked eye. In order to facilitate the use of paper-based probers for on-site semi-quantitative analysis, fluorescent color images can be digitized using a color analysis APP downloaded from a smartphone [36–39]. The difference in fluorescence of paper-based visual probes at different concentrations of TC was evaluated by digitizing the ratio of red (R) and blue (B) color intensities in the resulting fluorescence image. According to the R/B ratio plotted against TCs concentrations (Fig. 6), a linear curve can be fitted over a range of TCs concentrations from 0 to 9 μM. The linear equation is as follows:
= +y 0.316x 0.507,
where Y is the ratio of R/B and X is the TCs concentration. The lowest detectable concentration of the paper-based probe was 0.1 μM, which was approximately lower than the maximum residue limits of tetracycline allowed by the European Union (EU) (0.225 μM), and U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) (0.676 μM), respectively [40]. These results indicated that a visual and high sensitivity detection
method for TC real-time on-site detection has been established, the introduction of which eliminated the need for special reaction media or complex preparation processes.

sections.heading: 3.6. The photocatalytic degradation of TCs
sections.text:
Although there have been many studies on the detection or degradation of tetracyclines (TCs), there are few reports combining the detection and degradation functions of TCs integrated on one nanoplatform. To evaluate the photocatalytic activities of AC@Au nanocatalyst with different dosages under visible light irradiation, TCs were chosen as a model pollutant for photocatalytic degradation. For comparison, the photocatalytic activity of pure aminoclay was also investigated under the same condition.
As presented in Fig. 7a, the blank test indicated that the self-decomposition of TCs was impossible. When the AC@Au nanocatalyst were added to TCs samples and stirred for 30min in the dark, they can adsorb only ∼3% TCs molecules, indicating the small specific surface area. Subsequently, the whole photodegradation of TCs required another 40min irradiation. For pure aminoclay, the degradation efficiency can just reach to 76.81% after 40min of reaction. As compared to pure aminoclay, the AC@Au (1.32 wt%) nanocatalyst displayed more superior photocatalytic performance. This Au-modified aminoclay nanomaterial had a highly efficient photoinduced electron-hole pair separation effect, giving the material excellent photocatalytic properties [41]. And the apparent rate constant (Kapp) of AC@Au (1.32 wt%) was 0.1509min−1, which was significantly higher than other nanocatalyst reported in the literature (as shown in Table 2). To compare the photocatalytic oxidation activities with other aminoclay–metal nanoparticles published in the literature, the photocatalytic reaction rate constant of AC@Au nanocatalyst was than expressed as k= kapp / N [42], where N represents the mass ratio of photocatalyst (Mcat) and TCs (MTCs). The parameters in Table 2 indicated that the unit mass of the AC/Au nanocatalyst we prepared had a very high degradation rate of TCs during per unit time. From this comparison data it can be observed that the catalytic activity of AC@Au reported here was about 52.1 times faster than that of Au-TiO2/PDA/PVDF [44] and 40.8 times faster than Au/Pt/g-C3N4 [45]. This result also demonstrated that the AC@Au nano-platform not only can serve as a promising nanodetector for TCs, but also can play an important role in the subsequent photodegradation of TCs.
Meanwhile, the concentration of TCs in actual samples may vary greatly [41]. As presented in Fig. 7b, we configured the tetracycline solution according to the following concentration at 20, 120, 180, and
240mg/L, respectively. When the TCs concentration was between 20 and 120mg/L, the AC@Au nanocatalyst can always maintain high degradation efficiency (more than 88.25%). When the concentration of TCs was continuously increased, the photodegradation efficiency was significantly reduced, from 66.64% (180mg/L) to 26.27% (240mg/L). The reasons for the reduction can be drawn from two points: (1) High concentrations of TCs will increase the difficulty of photons entering the reaction system and drastically reduce the numbers of photons on the AC@Au surface. (2) At high concentrations, there is a competition between the degradation products of the TCs and TCs on the surface of the nanocatalyst; When the concentration of degradation products increased, the contact of the original TCs with the photocatalyst was greatly reduced [41,51].
As the stability and recyclability of the photocatalyst are significant factors in their practical application, we conducted five cycles of experiments to verify the stability of the AC@Au catalyst, as shown in Fig. 8a. Within the same irradiation time (∼40min), more than ∼98% TCs was photodegraded even after five successive cycles, demonstrating its high stability and great application value [52].
The main active substances in the photocatalytic reaction are of great significance for deriving the photocatalytic mechanism. So we examined the possible effects of several inhibitors on the photocatalytic activity, including isopropanol (IPA, %OH scavengers), ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium (EDTA
and EDTA-2Na, h+ scavengers), ammonium oxalate (AO, h+ scavengers) and 1.4-benzoquinone (BQ, %O2– scavengers) [45,50,53]. As indicated in Fig. 8b and c, the degradation efficiency of TCs declined slowly from 93.64% to 92.33% with the addition of IPA, indicating a very low inhibition. While the degradation efficiency of TCs decreased quickly from 98.1% to 24.1%, 33.5%, 18.2% or 37.3% when BQ, EDTA, EDTA-2Na or AO existed, indicating the %O2– and h+ were of great significance. Meanwhile, the apparent rate constants of various quenchers also decreased from 0.15086min−1 (no scavenger) to 0.08993min−1 (IPA), 0.01011min−1 (BQ), 0.01731min−1 (EDTA), 0.00833min−1 (EDTA-2Na) and 0.01331min−1 (AO) (Fig. 8d), which revealed that ⋅O2– radicals and h+ primarily contributed to the photoactivity enhancement in TCs photocatalytic degradation by AC@Au nanocatalyst [43].
The optical properties of the catalysts can provide useful information for the region of the absorption spectrum of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 9a, the UV–vis image of pure aminoclay exhibited a short-wavelength absorption with an edge at ∼550 nm and wavelength was higher than that of the published g-C3N4 or BiVO4 semiconductors [49,54]. We speculated that this may be the reason that the pure aminoclay still displayed good photocatalytic properties. After the modification of Au nanoparticles onto the pure aminoclay surface, the absorption edge of AC@Au nanocatalyst red shifted to ∼800 nm, accompanied by a new absorption peak at 550 nm, which was a direct
evidence of the typical localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) performance of Au nanoparticles. [43,55].
Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy generally provides useful information for the excitation and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers in photocatalysis [49,56]. The mass normalized PL emission spectra displayed in Fig. 9b compare the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron−hole pairs in aminoclay and AC@Au. As a matter of fact, the lower the PL signals, the better the photoinduced electronhole pairs' separation efficiency. As shown in Fig. 9b, pure aminoclay displayed the higher PL intensity, while AC@Au nanocatalyst possessed the relatively lower intensity. This phenomenon also demonstrated that the photoinduced electrons cannot join with holes pairs during the photocatalytic processes was efficiently inhibited due to the integration of aminoclay and Au nanoparticles [57]. And the AC@Au photocatalyst displayed better photodegradation rate to TCs than the pure aminoclay.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In brief, the fabrication of a new aminoclay based nano-platform for the selective and rapid sensitive detection as well as photodegradation
of tetracyclines from water were reported. These bi-functional applications just like the double-faced god in ancient Greek mythology (which also calls “Janus”), one of which can complete the visual detection of TCs while the other can achieve the simultaneous photodegradation of TCs. The detection limit of AC@Au-Cit-Eu toward TCs was estimated to be 11.2 nM/5.31 ppb (5.31 ng/mL). Meanwhile, the AC@Au-Cit-Eu prepared test paper can realize fast analysis of TCs using the color-scanning APP in a smartphone. More importantly, the original AC@Au nano-platform displayed unprecedented visible-light-driven photodegradation efficiency with a 93.33% degradation rate in 40min for TCs and the reaction rate constant (15.1× 10−3 min−1) was significantly higher than other photocatalysts reported in literatures, thus providing a new convenient strategy for sensitive detection of trace tetracycline in food and the effective treatment of tetracycline pollution in water environment.

metadata.abstractText: Although there have been many studies on the detection or degradation of tetracyclines (TCs), there are few reports about the ability to combine the detection and degradation functions of TCs integrated on one nanoplatform. Herein we developed a facile strategy to synthesize citric acid and Eu grafted amionclay@Au nanocomposite (AC@Au-Cit-Eu) that exhibited remarkable effect on visual detection, while the original AC@Au nano-platform displayed unprecedented visible-light-driven photodegradation efficiency of TCs. The results show that the AC@Au-Cit-Eu nanosensor can achieve rapid visual inspection of antibiotic TC in aqueous solution and real milk samples. The detection limit of the nanosensor for TCs was 11.2 nM. More importantly, the test strip made with AC@Au-Cit-Eu can also realize the real-time detection of TC through the color scanning APP in the smartphone. Meanwhile, the results also proved that the AC@Au nano-platform had good photocatalytic performance with a 93.33% degradation rate in 40min for TCs and the reaction rate constant was significantly higher than many other photocatalysts. This strategy greatly reduced the lengthy process from discovery to disposal of antibiotic residues and greatly utilizes nanocomposites.
